conclusion: The diagram shows a change process: A → B → C
State A: p = 3 × 10³ Pa, V = 1 × 10⁻³ m³, T = 27°C = 300 K
State B: p = 2 × 10³ Pa, V = 2 × 10⁻³ m³
State C: p = 2 × 10³ Pa, V = 3 × 10⁻³ m³
For an ideal gas with constant mass, we can use the ideal gas law: PV = nRT
Since the amount of gas (n) and the gas constant (R) are constant throughout the process, we can write: P₁V₁/T₁ = P₂V₂/T₂
Convert temperature to Kelvin: T_A = 27°C + 273 = 300 K
Find the temperature in state C using state A: P_A × V_A / T_A = P_C × V_C / T_C
Rearranging to solve for T_C: T_C = (P_C × V_C × T_A) / (P_A × V_A)
Substitute values: T_C = (2 × 10³ Pa × 3 × 10⁻³ m³ × 300 K) / (3 × 10³ Pa × 1 × 10⁻³ m³)
Convert back to Celsius: T_C = 600 K - 273 = 327°C
The temperature of the gas in state C is 600 K or 327°C
